awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Integrated Chemical and Supercritical Carbon Dioxide (CO2) Energy Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/ commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project to address a technological innovation in energy storage. Energy storage is a critical technology for the energy utility industries offering more reliable and affordable energy supply, a cleaner environment, and stronger energy infrastructure. Specific advantages of energy storage include a robust energy supply during storms and other natural disasters, aiding response and recovery efforts. This technology may also keep power plants and the grid functioning in times of physical and cyber-security threats. The project enables excellent grid stability and power plant flexibility to accommodate the growth of various renewable energy technologies and the expansion of electrified transportation systems.  

This STTR Phase 1 project proposes to address a technological innovation in energy storage. The reduced Levelized Electricity Cost due to this storage can directly benefit the end-users and broader population in the US and across the globe.  Notably, existing mechanical storage technologies have many attractive features such as short to mid-load response, black start, robust, long life, safety, and efficiency, but these technologies are not good at meeting scalability, reliability, and compactness metrics. On the other hand, chemical storage has mid-load response, long-lifetime, and scalability, but is inadequate with regard to safety, short-load response, black start, and efficiency. The proposed solution allows energy companies to explore low-cost technologies that can offer better performance and can be easily integrated with existing fossil power plants. The primary innovation combines mechanical and chemical storage technologies so that the resultant technology adapts the best features to provide enhanced performance at a cheaper capital, operational, and maintenance cost. The hybrid mechanical and chemical system proposed here uses supercritical carbon dioxide (sCO2) as the mechanical storage component, while chemical storage is achieved using natural gas or hydrogen. This proposed technology is referred to as an integrated chemical and sCO2 energy storage (ICsCO2ES).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Due to changing global environmental emission regulation targets, there is a need for energy storage technologies that are nature friendly,efficient, low-cost, and installable with the existing power plants. The current storage technologies do not satisfy the necessary expected performance criteria of energy storage due to various inherent technical, design, operation, and economic constraints. For example, the mechanical storage technologies have many attractive features such asshort to mid load response, black start, robust, long life, safety, andefficiency, but are not good at meeting scalability, reliability, and compactness metrics. On the other hand, chemical storage has mid load response, long-lifetime, and scalability, but is inadequate with regardsto safety, short load response, black start, and efficiency. Thus, it is essential to explore hybrid, low-cost technologies that can offer better performance, that are easily installable with existing fossil power plants, and that can entirely eliminate emission release to theatmosphere. This proposal’s primary novel idea is to combine mechanicaland chemical storage technologies so that the resultant technologyadapts the best features of both to provide enhanced performance at acheaper capital cost. The hybrid mechanical and chemical system proposedhere uses supercritical carbon dioxide (sCO2) as the mechanical storage component, while chemical storage is achieved using natural gas orhydrogen. Compared to more traditional mechanical storage concepts suchas compressed air/ Compressed liquid air energy storage (CAES), the thermophysical properties of sCO2 are more suitable for power production and storage, and we anticipate overall costs will be lower due to the advantage of operating the working fluid near and above the critical point of CO2. The integration of chemical storage and compressed sCO2 storage would be more beneficial for economics associated with scalability, operability, and efficiency. This proposed technology can refer to as an integrated chemical and sCO2 energy storage (ICsCO2ES).The ICsCO2ES technology is technically strong on its fundamental principles, and it is currently at the conceptual stage. It requires further R&D to disseminate its full potential. The NSF 20-527solicitation supports the R&D of unproven and high-impact innovations that reduce carbon and improve the scalability at power plant capacity.The proposed energy storage technology uses CO2 as a working fluid; it can completely eliminate the carbon footprint on the environment. Due to its hybrid integration with chemical storage and critical pointoperation, it significantly improves scalability issues.


Last Modified: 10/08/2024
Modified by: Navin Manjooran
